awd_titl_txt: Topics in protein and RNA folding and dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Devarajan (Dave) Thirumalai at the University of Texas Austin is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods Program in the Chemistry Division and the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences. Professor Thirumalai creates novel, theoretical, computational models in order to address outstanding questions in biologically-related research. For example, there are many proteins that do not adopt well-defined structures, these are referred to as Intrinsically Disordered Proteins (IDPs). IDPs behave like synthetic polymers but still control many biological functions.  Professor Thirumalai uses computational models to predict the structure and reactions of IDPs with other IDPs as well as of IDPs with RNA (ribonucleic acid). The characteristics of RNA folding and interactions with unstructured proteins are of specific interest. Finally, the physical mechanisms by which molecular-sized motors, transport molecular "cargo" within cells are not well understood. Professor Thirumalai examines how these motors move and make their deliveries.  In addition to the potential for broad impact of this research in biotechnology, Professor Thirumalai is devoted to the training of new generations of students in interdisciplinary research.

In the last twenty years, it has become increasingly clear that nearly 40% of the proteome consists of the so-called low complexity IDPs, which are involved in a number of still unknown functions. A major goal of Professor Thirumalai's research is to develop reliable models that can quantitatively predict the structural and dynamical properties of IDPs. This first step is needed in order to understand how they interact with RNA and themselves in producing liquid droplets, which are recognized to be important, but whose properties are largely unknown. Another aspect of Professor Thirumalai's research deals with how RNA molecules fold, especially with the focus on the difficult problem of the mechanisms by which metal cations drive their folding. In addition, Thirumalai is keenly interested in uncovering the principles of RNA-RNA interactions.  These structures also form droplets by themselves and in interactions with IDPs. Finally, two-headed molecular motors (Myosin, Dynein, and Kinesin) are largely responsible for transport of cargos in cells. They achieve this complex task by walking along actin and microtubules (MTs) in a preferred direction. One of Professor Thirumalai's major goals is to elucidate, using a combination of sophisticated theory and simulations, the structural basis by which the motors coordinate the two heads in a way such that one head steps forward while the other is bound to actin or MTs. Professor Thirumalai uses theoretical ideas to predict the outcomes of experiments, which include the distribution of motor velocities. These results are critically needed in order to redesign motors for synthetic purposes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: There are three major areas of the proposed research. (1) Many eukaryotic proteins do not adopt well-defined structures. For this reason, these are referred to as Intrinsically Disordered Proteins (IDPs), which means they can only be described using  statistical language. In this sense,  behave more like synthetic polymers but still control many functions has emerged a new paradigm in biophysics. (2) Equally important are the characteristics of RNA (referred sometimes as ?dark matter? in biology) folding and interactions with unstructured proteins. How these molecules, especially the ones with low complexity sequences self-associate to form droplets without membranes is not understood. (3) Finally, the physical mechanisms of how motors function, which differ drastically from common automobiles in design, transport cargo within cells is not well understood. Examples that were considered included kinesin (transports cargo in cells) and condensin (helps genome folding). Novel theoretical and computational tools were created to advance our knowledge in these areas.  

Achievements: (1) In the last twenty years it has become increasingly clear that nearly 40% of the proteome consists of the so-called low complexity IDPs, which are involved in a number of still unknown functions.  To describe their properties and predict how they interact with each other as well with RNA,  computational models that can quantitatively predict the structural and dynamical properties of IDPs were developed.  Using these models,  the propensity to aggregate was determine in terms of the spectrum of states they explore as a monomer. The theory was used to explain the origin of multiple structures (polymorphism) in a broad class of IDPs. (2) How do divalent cations, especially Mg2+ control RNA folding? This has been a long-standing problem in RNA biophysics.  Novel computational tools were created to address this problem. Although not fully solved, the first detailed glimpse of ion-RNA interactions in determining the folding of a ribozyme and the central domain of the protein making machine, the ribosome, emerged. Surprisingly,  it was shown that Mg2+ binding is highly specific, which also explained the hierarchical folding of ribozymes.  New models have been developed to understand how low complexity RNA molecules self-assemble to form droplets. It was shown that the ground state, a hairpin has to fully unfold, in order to interact with other RNA chains. The free energy gap between the ground and excited states determines their propensities to self-associate, which means the precise length matters. (3) Two headed Molecular motors (Myosin, Dynein, and Kinesin) are largely responsible for transport of cargos in cells. They achieve this complex task by walking along actin and microtubules (MTs) in a preferred direction.  During the walking process, only one head detaches from actin or microtubule. How do the two heads communicate? Using information theory, we showed that efficient communication can only occur if the resisting force is less than a critical value, which implies that under cellular conditions the motors operate only under low forces.  In another development,  theoretical methods were used to predict the mitotic (at cell division)structures of chromosomes. Surprisingly, it was predicted that the structures by helix perversion in which the handedness of the helices change along the length of the chromosomes. This analogous to similar structures in creeping plants, discussed in detail by Darwin and very familiar in old fashioned twists in telephone cords.  Collectively, these achievements have had broad impact on science, including training of new generation of students and postdoctoral fellows in interdisciplinary research and has the potential for impact in biotechnology.
